skill.name: medchem
skill.description: Medicinal chemistry filters. Apply drug-likeness rules (Lipinski, Veber), PAINS filters, structural alerts, complexity metrics, for compound prioritization and library filtering.

skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: No data theft or malicious execution patterns were found. The script performs local file I/O for molecule filtering and reporting only.

content.user_title: Apply medchem filters to compound libraries
content.value_statement: You need to prioritize compounds and remove problematic structures. This skill applies standard rules and alerts to deliver clean, comparable results.
actual_capabilities: Filter molecules with multiple medicinal chemistry rules in one run
Run structural alert checks including common alerts, NIBR, Lilly, and PAINS
Calculate molecular complexity scores and apply thresholds
Apply property constraints such as MW, LogP, TPSA, and rotatable bonds
Detect specified chemical groups across a molecule list
limitations: Requires local Python packages including medchem, datamol, pandas, and RDKit
Input formats limited to CSV, TSV, SDF, or TXT with SMILES
Filters provide guidelines and do not guarantee biological success
No automatic model training or predictive scoring

use_cases.title: Triage screening library
use_cases.description: Apply Rule of Five and PAINS filters to shortlist drug-like candidates.

use_cases.title: Lead optimization screening
use_cases.description: Combine leadlike rules with Lilly demerits and complexity thresholds.

use_cases.title: Batch quality control
use_cases.description: Process CSV and generate a summary report for compound quality metrics.

prompt_templates.title: Basic library filter
prompt_templates.scenario: New user wants simple drug-like filtering
prompt_templates.prompt: Filter my CSV library using Rule of Five and Veber, then report how many compounds pass.

prompt_templates.title: Alerts and PAINS
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to exclude problematic structures
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply common alerts and PAINS filters to my SMILES list and summarize the pass rate.

prompt_templates.title: Lead optimization set
prompt_templates.prompt: Run leadlike strict rules plus Lilly demerits and complexity max 400 on my SDF file.

prompt_templates.title: Custom constraints
prompt_templates.prompt: Filter molecules with MW 200 to 500, LogP -2 to 5, TPSA max 140, and report violations.

output_examples.input: Filter my CSV with Rule of Five and common alerts, and give me a summary.
output: Summary report saved alongside the output CSV

best_practices: Start with broad filters before applying strict lead optimization rules
Use parallel jobs for large libraries to speed processing
Document which filters were applied for reproducibility
anti_patterns: Treating filter results as final go or no go decisions
Skipping validation of invalid or missing SMILES entries
Mixing incompatible input formats in a single run

faq.question: What platforms can I use this with?
faq.answer: It works in Python environments that can run medchem, datamol, pandas, and RDKit.

faq.question: Are there limits on file size or molecule count?
faq.answer: No hard limits are set, but very large files depend on local memory and CPU.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with existing pipelines?
faq.answer: Yes, you can call the script in batch jobs or use the medchem API in your code.

faq.question: Does it send my data anywhere?
faq.answer: No, it reads local input files and writes local outputs only.

faq.question: What should I check if a run fails?
faq.answer: Verify required packages, confirm input format, and check that the SMILES column exists.

faq.question: How does this compare to manual filtering?
faq.answer: It applies standardized rules consistently, which improves repeatability over manual checks.
